user_request: A romantic poem about two hearts beating as one.

revision_history.draft:
Morning comes

before either of you
know what's happening—
your hand extends, finds the glass,
and somewhere in that narrow
corridor between sleep and light
your fingers touch mine.

Not seeking. Not reaching.
The way a pulse will find its own
cadence in stillness: 92,
then 86, then 90—the body's
tighter clock than any church.

Dawn presses flat against the window.
You drink. The water column
jumps slightly, as things do
near anything vibrating at almost
the right frequency.

Your thumb on the glass. My blood
moving through a vein just below
your wrist visible to neither of us—
we are doing this the way animals sync:
not beautifully, not for anyone,
just for the moment there is no
moment between: beat. pause.
beat.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The central conceit is genuinely strong: heartbeat as a private, unspoken rhythm that happens before anyone else notices — and the poem stays inside the body rather than reaching for moonlight or hands. The pulse-reading scene (line 5–8) has real specificity: "92, / then 86, then 90" is precise enough to feel like a genuine act of monitoring, not decoration.

The water column "jumps slightly" in response to the vibrating thumb — that's a concrete physical consequence. It shows rather than tells what happens when two rhythms come close without merging.

The closing beat/pause structure (beat. pause./beat./pause.) is effective as a formal echo of the content: no declaration, just repetition that builds tension through variation.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Cliché proximity:** "Dawn presses flat against the window" — this is atmospheric language doing mood work rather than specific sensory work. Pressing flat is decorative. What does it actually look like? The poem earns precision in pulse rates but then softens into impressionism here.

**Abstraction bloat (lines 13–20):** "The body's tighter clock than any church" — this collapses the physical observation back into abstraction. It tells us what the pulse is, instead of letting the earlier specificity do that work. Direction: cut or replace with a concrete image as precise as the 92/86 sequence.

**Redundancy:** The word "not" appears twice in succession ("Not seeking. Not reaching.") — this reads as filler to avoid saying "reaching out." Choose one, or find language that doesn't need negation to set up the next phrase.

**Weak line break (line 10):** "the way a pulse will find its own / cadence in stillness" — the break after "stillness" is doing nothing interesting. It doesn't create tension, surprise, or enjambment energy. Direction: either make the line break part of something or cut it entirely.

**Sentimentality risk:** The poem's final beat/pause gesture risks becoming a cliché of intimacy without pressure. It needs one more physical detail — something as specific as the wrist-vein scene — to ground it in the body and avoid coyness.

### Revision Direction

The draft has found its core engine: heartbeat-as-private-rhythm performed through concrete domestic images. Clean up the final beat/pause sequence by anchoring it in a second physical image alongside or instead of the repetition. Tighten lines 1–8 — cut "not seeking" / "not reaching," and sharpen the window/light/distance imagery into something as precise as the pulse-reading scene. The poem is close; those last five lines are where it needs to find its final pressure.

This poem has found its shape

Morning comes

your hand extends, finds the glass,
and somewhere in that narrow
corridor between sleep and light
your fingers touch mine.

The kitchen faucet runs its thin
constant argument near the window—
you drink. The water column
jumps slightly, as things do
near anything vibrating at almost
the right frequency.

Your thumb on the glass. My blood
moving through a vein just below
your wrist visible to neither of us—
we are doing this the way animals sync:
not beautifully, not for anyone,
just for the moment there is no
moment between: beat. pause.
beat—the faucet's thin argument
touching the rim of your mug.

Dawn thins against the window
as if something exhales across it,
the room split into cold and color
and colder, each half holding
the shape the other barely made.

Your thumb leaves a smudge.
The glass holds it like a kind of
argument for what happened—yes,
it happened. Here. On this surface.
Not beautiful. Just the frequency
that kept us both awake in any case.

revision_history.draft:
You leave your palm flat on the counter,
the kitchen holding its one still pose
between night's complete absence and
whatever the window intends—thin
grey, thin gray, that exhalation.

Your thumb finds the glass. Mine.
The water column in the faucet talks
to a blade of biscuit dust and jumps
its pitch a little, sympathetic
animal, sympathetic, the way
you adjust your mug so it doesn't
touch the rim, both hands open like

the surface matters more than either of us.

Dawn comes down the window's edge,
not thick yet—more an absence
exhaled across the panes, cold room
split into colder and a kind of light
that will not keep its shape. Your thumb
leaves a smudge. The glass holds it

like a fingerprint for what happened:
the frequency that kept us both awake,
neither seeking, neither surface
we could have chosen differently—just the
repeating thinness: tap, pause, tap,
the column holding its small argument
near the lip of your mug, near the edge,

and between us the counter, and between
us only the light deciding.

You leave your palm flat on the counter,
the kitchen holding its one still pose
between night's complete absence and
thin grey, that exhalation.

Your thumb finds the glass. Mine.
The water column in the faucet talks
to a blade of biscuit dust and drops
its pitch, sympathetic animal, the way
you adjust your mug so it doesn't
touch the rim, both hands open like

the surface matters more than either of us.

Between the panes, dawn splits the cold room into colder sections,
and light thinning at the window.

Your thumb leaves a smudge.
The glass holds it

like a thinning — the way light finds the crack
between two things and almost
forgets it is light—just the crack,

and between us the counter, and between
us only the faucet's tick, the dust
on the blade of bread, the grey
exhalation thickening at the window.

I read the glass wrong. It wasn't
a fingerprint but a thinning,
the way light narrows where two panes meet
and almost stops being light—just the split,

and between us the faucet
holds its single note.
The dust doesn't settle on anything.

Tap, pause, tap. The column argues
near the lip of your mug, near the edge,

and in the crack between those things
the thinness lives: not resolution,
not absence, just the narrow
argument the pipe keeps winning—water
against glass, pressure finding its purchase

on the rim of your cup, on my thumb,
on the counter where we started.
